pages.title: About OpenData
pages.text: OpenData is a database of publicly available datasets of potential interest to the Niv/Daw labs. We are mostly cataloging datasets involving reinforcement learning & decision making experiment, though we also keep tabs on computational psychiatry experiments and some self-report questionnaires. To browse the current catalog, follow the links above or use the search bar at the top-right of this page.

pages.title: Contributing to OpenData
pages.text: Contributions to OpenData are welcome! All of the code is managed through the GitHub repository. How to submit a datasetThere are three main ways you can submit a dataset for entry to OpenData, which are described in turn below. Note that they are ranked in order of preference, from most preferred to least preferred, by the maintainers of Open Data :) 1. Submit a pull requestTo directly add a dataset yourself, you can open a pull request on Github. First you should fork the OpenData library via GitHub and make modifications on your fork. The OpenData database is written in markdown using a standardized, easy-to-copy template. Once your modification is complete, submit a pull request to merge your changes into the docs branch of OpenData. Pull requests will be reviewed by the maintainers. 2. Open an issueTo advertise a dataset for entry into the database, you can open a new issue via GitHub. Please provide a link to a repository for the data and, if available, a link to a corresponding manuscript describing the data. 3. Email the maintainersA third and final way to advertise a dataset for entry into the database is to email the maintainers directly (zorowitz@princeton.edu). Please provide a link to a repository for the data and, if available, a link to a corresponding manuscript describing the data.

posts.title: Albrecht et al. (2016)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=75 participants (N=45 patients with schizophrenia, N=30 healthy controls) completed the Pavlovian go/no-go task.

posts.title: Bach (2015)
posts.text: Data from a study in in which a total of N=83 participants across four experiments (N=20, N=21, N=22, N=20) completed a novel approach/avoidance sequential decision making task. The state/trait anxiety inventory was collected for all participants.

posts.title: Bach et al. (2020)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=781 young adults (aged 14-24) completed a risky foraging task.

posts.title: Ballard et al. (2019)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=32 participants completed a target detection task involving configural learning.

posts.title: Bavard et al. (2021)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=800 participants completed a novel range adaptation task.

posts.title: Bennett, Radulescu et al. (2021)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=120 participants completed a novel compound generalization task with mood inductions and eye-tracking.

posts.title: Bertram et al. (2021)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=281 participants across two experiments (N=162, N=119) in which participants estimated the probabilities of neutral compound events and rated their current mood.

posts.title: Cavanagh et al. (2019)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=46 depressed individuals completed the probabilistic selection task.

posts.title: Chambon et al. (2020)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=102 participants across four experiments (N=24, N=24, N=30, N=24) completed a series of 2-arm bandit tasks involving partial vs. complete feedback, free vs. fixed choice trials, and go vs. no-go responses.

posts.title: Collins (2018)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=49 participants completed a reinforcement learning task with working memory demands.

posts.title: Correa et al. (2018)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=32 participants completed a novel reversal learning task in which the visibility of reward was manipulated.

posts.title: Csifcsak et al. (2020)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=46 participants completed a modified pavlovian go/no-go task where the probability of outcomes was modified across blocks of the experiment.

posts.title: Csifcsak et al. (2021)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=103 participants completed a modified pavlovian go/no-go task where the probability of outcomes was modified across blocks of the experiment.

posts.title: Decker et al. (2016)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=80 participants (N=30 children, N=28 adolescents, N=22 adults) completed the two-step task.

posts.title: Dezfouli et al. (2019)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=101 participants (N=34 healthy controls, N=34 unipolar depressed patients, N=33 bipolar depressed patients) completed a 2-arm bandit task.

posts.title: Dorfman & Gershman (2019)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=454 participants completed the Pavlovian go/no-go task wherein outcome controllability was manipulated.

posts.title: Erev et al. (2017)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=686 participants completed a decisions from descriptions task involving 210 unique gamble types.

posts.title: Fan et al. (2021)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=984 participants across two experiments (N=531, N=556 before exclusions) completed a 2-arm bandit task with drifting rewards. Participants completed multiple self-report measures of anxiety.

posts.title: Fradkin et al. (2020)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=58 participants completed a multi-arm reversal learning task. The OCI was collected to measure compulsivity symptoms.

posts.title: Franklin & Frank (2020)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=482 participants across three experiments (N=198, N=153, N=151) completed a novel grid-world task in which participants had to learn the mapping between goal values and button-response mappings across multiple contexts.

posts.title: Frey et al. (2017)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=1507 participants completed 39 risk-taking measures (e.g. decisions from description, BART, CCT), with a subsample of 109 participants completing a retest session after 6 months).

posts.title: Gagne et al. (2020)
posts.text: The data from a study in which N=233 participants across two experiments (N=86, N=147) completed a probabilistic volatility task and a series of self-report psychiatric symptom measures.

posts.title: Gillan et al. (2016)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=1961 participants across two experiments (N=548, N=1413) completed the two-step task and multiple self-report psychiatric symptom questionnaires.

posts.title: Gillan et al. (2020)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=138 participants across two experiments (N=88, N=50) completed the two-step task while undergoing inhalation of hypercapnic gas.

posts.title: Glockner & Pachur (2012)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=66 participants completed a decisions from description paradigm twice, separated by 1 week.

posts.title: Goris et al. (2019)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=161 participants completed a multi-arm risk sensitivity task and the autism quotient questionnaire.

posts.title: Hammond et al. (2020)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=125 participants across two experiments (N=76, N=49) completed a probabilistic volatility task and a series of self-report psychiatric symptom measures.

posts.title: Heffner et al. (2021)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=1006 participants across four experiments complete an economic (ultimatum) game to investigate the influence of emotion prediction errors on social choice. Participants also completed multiple self-report measures.

posts.title: Hein et al. (2021)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=42 participants completed a probabilistic volatility task.

posts.title: Homan et al. (2019)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=77 participants (combat veterans) completed a threat discrimination and reversal task.

posts.title: Hunter et al. (2021)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=741 participants completed an economic game (patent race) involving planning and multiple self-report psychiatric symptom questionnaires.

posts.title: Jang et al. (2019)
posts.text: Data from a study of N=287 participants on a 2-arm bandit task with volatile reward probabilities and a surprise recognition memory task.

posts.title: Jean-Richard-dit-Bressel (2021)
posts.text: Data from a study of N=135 participants on a gamified instrumental contingency learning task involving avoidable punishments.

posts.title: Klein et al. (2017)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=75 participants completed a 2-arm bandit task with novel choice options introduced throughout the task.

posts.title: Konstantinidis et al. (2018)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=202 participants completed a risky 2-arm bandit task, which examined how the magnitude of prospective outcomes impact risk preferences.

posts.title: Lamba et al. (2020)
posts.text: Data from a study in which of N=354 participants (N=257 healthy controls, N=97 clinically anxious) completed an economic (trust) game with drifting levels of reciprocity. Participants also completed self-report measures of anxiety.

posts.title: Lefebvre et al. (2017)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=85 participants performed a simple 2-arm bandit task with different reward probabilities (75/25, 25/25, 75/75).

posts.title: Marton et al. (2019)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=70 participants (N=44 healthy controls, N=26 OCD patients) completed the random-dot motion task (RDMT) with varying levels of coherence. Participants rated their confidence after making their judgments.

posts.title: McDonald et al. (2019)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=82 participants completed a complex multiplayer “penalty shot” game.

posts.title: Millner et al. (2018)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=52 participants completed a modified pavlovian go/no-go task wherein participants had to either prevent or escape from aversive stimuli.

posts.title: Mkrtchian et al. (2017)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=101 participants (N=58 healthy controls, N=43 patients with mood & anxiety disorders) completed the pavlovian go/no-go task.

posts.title: Moran et al. (2019)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=47 participants completed a complex two-stage bandit task with drifting reward probabilities.

posts.title: Moutoussis et al. (2018)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=817 participants (aged 14-24) who completed the pavlovian go/no-go task task.

posts.title: Najar et al. (2020)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=370 participants across three experiments (N=24, N=44, N=302) in a novel social reinforcement learning task designed to study adaptive imitation.

posts.title: Niv et al. (2012)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=16 participants completed a 2-arm bandit task measuring preferences between certain and risky reward options.

posts.title: Nussenbaum et al. (2020)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=151 participants (N=50 children N=50 adolescents, N=51 adults) completed the two-step task.

posts.title: Palminteri et al. (2016)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=50 participants (N=24 adults, N=26 adolescents) completed a 2-arm bandit task involving partial and counterfactual feedback.

posts.title: Palminteri et al. (2017)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=40 participants completed a 2-arm bandit task with and without counterfactual feedback.

posts.title: Pederson et al. (2021)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=56 participants (N=35 healthy controls, N=21 depressed patients) completed an approach/avoidance task.

posts.title: Peterson et al. (2021)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=14,711 participants completed a decisions from description task. Involves the largest number of unique decision choice problems (13,006) to date.

posts.title: Pool et al. (2021)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=327 completed an outcome devaluation task with overtraining. Participants also completed multiple self-report psychiatric symptom questionnaires.

posts.title: Potter et al. (2017)
posts.text: Daa from a study in which N=69 participants (N=22 children, N=23 adolescents, N=24 adults) completed the two-step task and several measures of executive functioning.

posts.title: Raab & Hartley (2020)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=61 participants (N=20 children, N=20 adolescents, N=21 adults) completed the pavlovian go/no-go task.

posts.title: Radulescu et al. (2020)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=563 participants completed a 2-arm bandit measuring preferences between certain and risky reward options.

posts.title: Rahnev et al. (2020)
posts.text: The Confidence Database contains +145 datasets with data from more than 8,700 participants and almost 4 million trials.

posts.title: Reed et al. (2020)
posts.text: Data from a study in which 364 participants completed a 3-arm probabilistic reversal-learning paradigm.

posts.title: Robinson et al. (2019)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=132 participants (N=88 healthy controls, N=44 patients with mood and anxiety symptoms) completed a 4-arm restless bandit task.

posts.title: Rouhani et al. (2018)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=308 participants across three experiments (N=174, N=148, N=86) completed a novel outcome prediction task probing the link between reward prediction errors and memory.

posts.title: Rouhani & Niv (2021)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=766 participants across three experiments (N=81, N=331, N=354) completed a novel outcome prediction task probing the link between reward prediction errors and memory.

posts.title: Rutledge et al. (2021)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=47,067 participants completed a risky decision and happiness task. Participants completed the task a total of 91,058 times making approximately 2.7 million choices and 1.1 million happiness ratings in total. A subset of 1,858 participants also completed a depression questionnaire and answered five questions about their depression history.

posts.title: Safra et al. (2019)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=200 participants completed a novel bandit task with different levels of social information (absent, partial and complete). Participants also completed self-report measures of depression.

posts.title: Seow et al. (2020)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=196 participants completed the Flanker task and multiple self-report psychiatric symptom measures.

posts.title: Shin & Niv (2021)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=806 participants across eight experiments (N=76, N=22, N=626, N=182) where participants completed tasks where they observed a sequence of social or non-social behaviours and estimated their average.

posts.title: Sugawara & Katahira (2021)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=150 participants completed a series of 2-arm bandit tasks involving different reward probabilities (75/25, 25/25, 75/75) and feedback types (partial, counterfactual).

posts.title: Swart et al. (2017)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=106 participants completed the pavlovian go/no-go task.

posts.title: Swart et al. (2018)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=34 participants completed the pavlovian go/no-go task.

posts.title: Thomas et al. (2019)
posts.text: Data from four studies (N=39, N=30, N=24, N=25) in which participants either a 2-arm bandit task or a perceptual decision making task while eye position was recorded.

posts.title: Tomov et al. (2021)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=1128 participants across four experiments (N=226, N=202, N=200, N=500) completed a novel two-step decision-making task with multiple features and changing reward functions.

posts.title: Turi et al. (2017)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=29 participants completed the probabilistic selection task multiple times to investigate placebo effects on reward learning.

posts.title: van Baar et al. (2021)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=501 participants across four experiments predicted other players’ decisions across four economic games (the Harmony Game, the Snowdrift Game, Stag Hunt and Prisoner’s Dilemma).

posts.title: Waltmann et al. (2021)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=40 participants completed a probabilistic reversal learning task twice.

posts.title: Warren et al. (2017)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=22 participants completed the horizons task, a measure of explore-exploit behaviors.

posts.title: Widge et al. (2019)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=14 patients with deep brain stimulation for depression completed an affective Stroop task twice, once with DBS-ON and once with DBS-OFF.

posts.title: Wise et al. (2019)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=65 participants completed an aversive learning task featuring two stimuli that were each independently associated with varying probabilities of electric shocks.

posts.title: Wise et al. (2020)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=400 participants completed a gamified 2-arm reversal learning bandit task and multiple self-report psychiatric symptom measures.

posts.title: Wu et al. (2018)
posts.text: Data from study in which N=241 participants across three experiments (N=81, N=80, N=80) completed a novel grid-world task in which participants sought rewards under limited search horizons and spatial autocorrelation.

posts.title: Wulff et al. (2018)
posts.text: Data from an aggregate of 28 publications of experiments studying decisions from description and experience.

posts.title: Zaller et al. (2021)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=99 participants completed the horizons task and multiple self-report measures of anxiety.

posts.title: Zhu et al. (2019)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=32 participants (N=20 healthy controls, N=12 patients with focal lesions) completed an economic game (patent race) involving planning.

posts.title: Zorowitz et al. (2021)
posts.text: Data from a study in which N=386 participants completed a 3-arm reversal learning task and multiple self-report symptom measures.
